title: Ringworm 101: What It Is and How to Get Rid of It

content: As a dermatologist, I evaluate rashes of all kinds, day in and day out. In fact, during our specialty training, dermatologists study over 3,000 different conditions of the skin, hair, and nails. Most of these are diseases we’ve never heard of – talk about a steep learning curve – but one thing we’re all too familiar with is ringworm.

Let’s get one thing straight right off the bat – “ringworm” is not caused by a worm. Despite its name, ringworm actually refers to a superficial fungal infection. Many different causative species can affect all ages and various body sites, including your torso, extremities, groin folds, face, and scalp (which can be extra tricky to treat. More on that later). Tinea infections are classified and named based on the body site affected:

Tinea flourishes in warm, humid climates and is spread via direct skin contact with an infected person or animal. Additional risk factors include wearing enclosed shoes or boots (think sweaty feet), using communal spaces such as showers or locker rooms, and having a compromised immune system.

sections.heading: What Does Ringworm Look Like?
content: Ringworm on the body typically appears round (hence the “ring” in “ringworm), shaped like an egg, in semicircular pink or red patches. There tends to be a prominent, elevated border, which may be a deeper red or purple color. There is often central clearing, in which the middle of the rash is significantly lighter in color. Lesions are scaly, may have a bumpy appearance to them, and are often itchy.

In body folds, such as between the toes or in groin folds, the affected area may appear macerated, meaning the skin appears moist and softened, often with a white or wrinkly quality. On your scalp, ringworm may cause scaling, flaking, pus bumps, and can even lead to broken hairs and hair loss. You may also have swollen lymph nodes.
Ringworm can be isolated or widespread. The number of lesions and areas on your body involved will determine the treatment recommended by your doctor.

content: A classic, textbook case of tinea may be diagnosed visually without diagnostic testing. However, it may be confused with some lookalike rashes in widespread or atypical cases. Some of these lookalikes include eczema, contact dermatitis, psoriasis, syphilis, bacterial infections, and other less common skin conditions such as granuloma annulare or cutaneous lupus.

Tinea may be suspected based on a simple visual inspection. To confirm the diagnosis, your doctor may scrape the scaly part of the lesion with a blade, put it on a glass slide, and look at it under the microscope. A positive sample will show long, branching filaments called hyphae, which indicate the presence of fungal organisms.

Alternatively, a fungal culture may be performed. This is a diagnostic test in which a skin sample is collected and sent to grow under controlled conditions in a microbiology lab. A fungal culture may be used to determine the specific type of fungus causing the rash. This knowledge can help your doctor select the most appropriate antifungal medication, as some fungal species have developed resistance to commonly prescribed drugs.

content: A skin biopsy can also be used to confirm the diagnosis. It is especially useful if a deeper infection is suspected, or if another type of rash is being considered.

Good news – there are many available treatments for ringworm! Mild cases with just a few lesions are typically treated with topical antifungals, such as ketoconazole and terbinafine creams, among others. The length of your treatment could vary, with some infections clearing fast and some requiring 6 weeks or more of therapy. You can also use diluted vinegar soaks, as vinegar has antifungal properties.

When ringworm fails to respond to creams or is widespread, affecting multiple body parts at once, your doctor may prescribe medication to be taken by mouth. For example, in tinea capitis, topical creams are ineffective, as they do not reach fungal organisms in your hair follicles. So, oral meds are needed in these cases.

Terbinafine, fluconazole, and griseofulvin are commonly prescribed oral medications. The choice depends on suspected organisms and emerging resistance patterns. Oral antifungal medications are known for having interactions with other medications. So, it’s important to tell your doctor about all the medications you’re taking and any prior medical problems before starting oral therapy.
